Issues.Title: refactor(core): missing-injectable migration should respect providers of directives and components
Issues.Body:
Currenly the `missing-injectable` migration only migrates providers referenced from
`@NgModule` definitions. The schematic currently does not cover the migration for
providers referenced in `@Directive` or `@Component` definitions.

We need to handle `providers` for both `@Directive` and `@Component`. Additionally
for components we need to respect the `viewProviders` field.

This commit ensures that the migration handles providers for these definitions.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(core): missing-injectable migration should respect providers of directives and components" (#33011)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): avoid exposing `ng` with Closure Compiler enhanced optimizations
Issues.Body:
Prior to this commit, `ng` was exposed in global namespace, which turned out to be problematic when minifying code with Closure, since it sometimes clobber our `ng` global. This commit aligns Ivy debugging tools behavior with existing logic in "platform-browser" package (packages/platform-browser/src/dom/util.ts#L31) by avoiding `ng` in global namespace when Closure Compiler is used.

Similar change was originally introduced in https://github.com/angular/angular/commit/a7798f2.

Note: if we want to expose debugging tools in Closure at some point in the future, we should be able to do that using a different namespace (like `ngDevTools`).

## PR Type

- [x] Bugfix

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): avoid exposing `ng` with Closure Compiler enhanced optimizations" (#33010)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): adding `ng` to externs list
Issues.Body:
Prior to this commit, Closure Compiler may accidentally use `ng` during minification process, which conflicts with `window.ng` that is exposed in dev mode for debugging. This commit adds `ng` into externs file to avoid such collisions.

Issues.Title: fix(common): ensures hash location strategy includes current path fro‚Ä¶
Issues.Body:
‚Ä¶m window.location.pathname

Previously with HashLocationStrategy, any url updates were only made with the hash, for example when the routerLink directives updates the href on anchor tags or in calls to history.pushState or history.replaceState. In the case that a base href is set though, the browser will actually update the url path in the address bar with the path included in the base href. During client side hash routing, this causes unexpected behavior. By always including the current location.pathname in history updates, this ensures that HashRouting will never cause a change to anything before the hash, which is what one would expect.

Fixes #33000

Issues.Title: ci: shorten the display name of `init_environment` steps that are shown in all jobs
Issues.Body:
The `init_environment` custom command is used in almost all other jobs. The this is implemented in CircleCI is that the steps of the command are inlined into the other jobs.

Some of the `init_environment` commands are quite long and (since the default display name for a step is its command) they clutter the CircleCI UI. Additionally, multiple related commands are shown as separate steps, which makes it more difficult to get to the actual steps of a job.

This commit improves this by:
1. Defining explicit, short names for steps with long commands.
2. Grouping multiple related steps into one.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "ci: shorten the display name of `init_environment` steps that are shown in all jobs" (#32998)

Issues.Title: Angular router in hash mode shouldn't modify the url before the hash
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package @angular/router ### Description **The problem:** _The angular router in hash mode changes the base of the url path in the address bar to the base href I have set in my index.html._ I would think that in hash mode, the angular router shouldn't care about anything in the url before the hash. This is a problem because: 1. This is contrary to default browser behavior (the url would otherwise remain unchanged regardless of my base href). 2. In the case that the request for the index.html page differs from the server location of the javascript and css files output from `ng build`, I need to set the base href if I need to load any of these static assets using relative urls. This would happen if I were using a CMS, if my index page were generated from something like dotnet MVC, or if I were using a CDN (depending on how my server and CDN were configured). The same was reported in #20033, but was closed as the issue did not contain any reproduction of the problem. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction I had to create a [repo](https://github.com/haydenbr/ng-hash-router-problem) since you can't change the base href in stackblitz. ### Steps to reproduce 1. clone the repo 2. `npm install` 3. `npm build` 4. `npm server` (just runs a simple express server to mimic having to set base href) 5. navigate to localhost:3000/Home in your browser (the server is serving the index.html file and javascript files from different locations. In particular, the javascript files are coming from `/dist/ng-hash-router-problem/` and the index.html file is coming from `/some-other-path/index.html`) I would expect the url to be `localhost:3000/Home/#/` after loading the application, but instead, the url is changed to `http://localhost:3000/dist/ng-hash-router-problem/#/`. So the url path was changed to the base href set in `/some-other-path/index.html`. If I then try to refresh the page, by browser is hit `http://localhost:3000/dist/ng-hash-router-problem/#/` instead of the originally requested url, `localhost:3000/Home/#/`, and the page breaks because it cannot load the files from the server. As a test, I removed the RouterModule from the app, and commented out any components or directives exported from the RouterModules so that app doesn't break, and the url path isn't changed, so it's definitely something in the RouterModule. Similarly, if I set `initialNavigation: 'disabled'` in the RouterModule Extra Options, the url path is not changed until the first time I navigate. ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 8.3.7
Node: 10.15.3
OS: darwin x64
Angular: 8.2.9
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router

Package                           Version
-----------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect         0.803.7
@angular-devkit/build-angular     0.803.7
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer   0.803.7
@angular-devkit/build-webpack     0.803.7
@angular-devkit/core              8.3.7
@angular-devkit/schematics        8.3.7
@angular/cli                      8.3.7
@ngtools/webpack                  8.3.7
@schematics/angular               8.3.7
@schematics/update                0.803.7
rxjs                              6.4.0
typescript                        3.5.3
webpack                           4.39.2
## Other notes My express config is probably not "correct". Please don't comment on that. It's just a throw-together server to illustrate the problem that happens when I have to set base href. For the sake of the problem, please assume that I cannot change the server configuration or location of the files being served. It shouldn't be a browser specific problem, but my Chrome version is 77.0.3865.90 (Official Build) (64-bit) ### Existing work arounds I don't think I should have to take an extra step to get this to work because I am expecting to be able to use default browser behavior. Angular shouldn't prevent default browser behavior. 1. I could probably get the url to behave like I want by implementing my own LocationStrategy, but this seems like an unnecessary extra step 2. I could not set a base href and instead use `--deploy-url` when building (or set `buildUrl` in `angular.json`) but this is again an extra step that I shouldn't have to do if I could take advantage of default browser behavior. This is also a challenge because the deploy url might change per environment or per server. It's easier to set a base href because the server would know about any CDN configuration or where my files are expected to be located, but I might not have this knowledge per environment when building the front end. And this is also more configuration I have to be responsible for when otherwise the server could just set the base href. ### Existing code I spent a lot of time sifting through the angular codebase, but couldn't nail down the cause. I did see in [location_stategy.ts](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/1537791f06df5d85dd27e763836fd99bb1530991/packages/common/src/location/location_strategy.ts) where `PathLocationStrategy` gets the base href from the dom and uses this as the base of the url path, but I guess that would be expected for PathLocation. I could be wrong, but I couldn't find anything in [hash_location_strategy.ts](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/1537791f06df5d85dd27e763836fd99bb1530991/packages/common/src/location/hash_location_strategy.ts) that was changing the url path. It _seems_ that HashLocationStrategy is leaving the url alone, but something else somewhere must be incorrectly changing the url path. This is again as I would expect since hash mode _should_ only be concerned with the url after the hash. I will continue to search the codebase as I have time and submit a PR to fix the issue if I can find it, but I wanted to make you all aware and validate that this is a defect that should be fixed. (I can't imagine why this behavior would be intentional).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Angular router in hash mode shouldn't modify the url before the hash" (#33000)

Issues.Title: Improve performance of attributes setting
Issues.Body:
Accessing a string's character at index allocates a new, single character string.
A better (faster) check is to use `charCodeAt` that doesn't trigger allocation.

This simple change speeds up the element_text_create benchmark by ~7%.

Issues.Title: Produce warnings/errors for code that change detection can't handle
Issues.Body:
Examples: ### Creates new observable on every change detection cycle ```html
{{ x }}
``` > Maybe: Warning - Observables should not change on every change detection cycle. Create a single observable upfront instead ### Doesn't use trackBy ```html
[[ ... dozens of lines of dom & components ... ]]
``` > Maybe: Warning - Angular doesn't reuse the DOM tree inside ngFor right now. Consider adding trackBy for performance ~~### Create new reference on every single change detection:~~ ```html
{{ x }}
``` ~~> Maybe: Warning - The array reference should not change on every change detection cycle / or use pipe slice instead~~ Update: This case is handled by angular, my assumption was wrong --- These are footguns that rise from how angular works. For me these errors are super clear. But anybody that is not familiar with angular or doesn't work every day with it writes code like this all the time. And it's super hard to keep up with it in code reviews to not let those things slip into master. A little help from the framework to prevent these issues would be appreciated.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Produce warnings/errors for code that change detection can't handle" (#32995)

Issues.Title: fix(router): adjust UrlTree redirect to replace URL if in eager update
Issues.Body:
Resubmit #31168 now that google3 tests can pass. This requires http://cl/272696717 to be patched.
Original description from jasonaden:

Without this change when using UrlTree redirects in urlUpdateStrategy="eager", the URL would get
updated to the target location, then redirected. This resulted in having an additional entry in the
history and thus the back button would be broken (going back would land on the URL causing a new
redirect).

Additionally, there was a bug where the redirect, even without urlUpdateStrategy="eager", could
create a history with too many entries. This was due to kicking off a new navigation within the
navigation cancelling logic. With this PR the new navigation is pushed to the next tick with a
setTimeout, allowing the page being redirected from to be cancelled before starting a new
navigation.

Related to #27148

## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [x] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

- [x] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?
If a CanActivate guard returns a UrlTree, the router performs a redirect. Currently both the source and target of the redirect will exist in the browser history. So if the user hits the back button they will go back to the source of the redirect which will then redirect back to the page they were already on.

Issue Number: #27148


## What is the new behavior?
When a CanActivate guard returns a UrlTree, triggering a redirect, there will only be a single history entry containing the destination of the redirect. Hitting the back button will take the user to the previous page.

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No


<!-- If this PR contains a breaking change, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications below. -->


## Other information

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): allow abstract directives to have an invalid constructor
Issues.Body:
For abstract directives, i.e. directives without a selector, it may
happen that their constructor is called explicitly from a subclass,
hence its parameters are not required to be valid for Angular's DI
purposes. Prior to this commit however, having an abstract directive
with a constructor that has parameters that are not eligible for
Angular's DI would produce a compilation error.

A similar scenario may occur for `@Injectable`s, where an explicit
`use*` definition allows for the constructor to be irrelevant. For
example, the situation where `useFactory` is specified allows for the
constructor to be called explicitly with any value, so its constructor
parameters are not required to be valid. For `@Injectable`s this is
handled by generating a DI factory function that throws.

This commit implements the same solution for abstract directives, such
that a compilation error is avoided while still producing an error at
runtime if the type is instantiated implicitly by Angular's DI
mechanism.

Fixes #32981

---

TODO

- [ ] Adjust error message for abstract directives, it currently refers to `@Injectable`

Issues.Title: Issue with `fullTemplateTypeCheck` and `ng serve`
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? I don't know. ### Description When having `fullTemplateTypeCheck` enabled in `tsconfig.json` and running `ng serve` everything runs fine initially. I might, for example, get nice error messages about my template type-check issues (with colors and everything :smiley:): ``` ERROR in src/app/app.component.html:38:66 - error TS2322: Type 'SearchResults | null' is not assignable to type 'SearchResults | undefined'. Type 'null' is not assignable to type 'SearchResults | undefined'. 38 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ src/app/app.component.ts:23:16 23 templateUrl: './app.component.html', ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Error occurs in the template of component AppComponent. ``` Then on re-compiling (e.g. after editing a file and saving), I get the following error: ``` ERROR in ./src/main.ts at plugin.done.then ([...]\angular\aio\node_modules\@ngtools\webpack\src\loader.js:41:31) at process._tickCallback (internal/process/next_tick.js:68:7) ERROR in ./src/polyfills.ts Module build failed (from ./node_modules/@ngtools/webpack/src/index.js): Error: [...]\angular\aio\src\polyfills.ts is missing from the TypeScript compilation. Please make sure it is in your tsconfig via the 'files' or 'include' property. at AngularCompilerPlugin.getCompiledFile ([...]\angular\aio\node_modules\@ngtools\webpack\src\angular_compiler_plugin.js:918:23) at plugin.done.then ([...]\angular\aio\node_modules\@ngtools\webpack\src\loader.js:41:31) at process._tickCallback (internal/process/next_tick.js:68:7) i ÔΩ¢wdmÔΩ£: Failed to compile. ``` I might then get some error template type-check errors, but not as nicely formatted (or colorful) as before: ``` ERROR in src/app/app.component.html(38,66): error TS2322: Type 'SearchResults | null' is not assignable to type 'SearchResults | undefined'. Type 'null' is not assignable to type 'SearchResults | undefined'. src/app/app.component.html(47,63): error TS2322: Type 'NavigationNode[]' is not assignable to type 'Option[]'. Type 'NavigationNode' is not assignable to type 'Option'. Types of property 'title' are incompatible. Type 'string | undefined' is not assignable to type 'string'. Type 'undefined' is not assignable to type 'string'. src/app/app.component.html(47,87): error TS2322: Type 'NavigationNode' is not assignable to type 'Option'. src/app/custom-elements/api/api-list.component.html(24,8): error TS2322: Type 'ApiSection[] | null' is not assignable to type 'ApiSection[] | Iterable | undefined'. ... ``` After this first error, the app is not re-compiled when I make changes (I have to stop the process and run `ng serve` anew). (NOTE: The error seems only (or much more often) happen when there _are_ template type-check errors.) ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction It started happening for me in PR angular/angular#32980. To reproduce, you could: 1. Check out the PR. 2. Reset to the commit before ``build(docs-infra): enable `fullTemplateTypeCheck` (and fix failures)`` (currently https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/32980/commits/3f228a626). 3. Add `fullTemplateTypeCheck: true` in `aio/tsconfig.json > angularCompilerOptions`. 4. Run `yarn --cwd=aio && yarn --cwd=aio start`. _(You should see some nice template type-check error messages.)_ 5. Open `aio/src/app/app.component.ts`, make a change and save it. _(You should see the error.)_ (NOTE: If that reproduction isn't helpful, I can try to create a minimal one with a new app.) ## üåç Your Environment (NOTE: I am on 9.0.0-next.8 now, but this happened with 9.0.0-next.6 as well.)

Node: 10.16.3

Issues.Title: fail with library use angular8 loadChildren format
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... No, it's just come up with angular8 new loadChildren format ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... when I try to use `import(...)` to lazyload route in library, it come up with error, I think the reason is rollup configuration for library doesn't support multiple chunk, when I change to use old loadChildren format like `loadChildren: './admin-user-login.module#AdminUserLoginModule'` it's works well ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 1. generate a route as a library ```s ng g library admin-user-login ``` 2. add route define for module ```ts // projects/admin-user-login/src/lib/admin-user-login.route.ts import { Route, Routes } from '@angular/router'; import { AdminUserLoginComponent } from './admin-user-login.component'; export const AdminUserLoginRouteEntry: Route = { path: 'login', // loadChildren: './admin-user-login.module#AdminUserLoginModule', // works well async loadChildren() { const { AdminUserLoginModule } = await import('./admin-user-login'); // error, because import make multiple chunks. return AdminUserLoginModule; }, } export const AdminUserLoginRouteChildren: Routes = [ { path: '', component: AdminUserLoginComponent, } ] // projects/admin-user-login/src/lib/admin-user-login.module.ts import { NgModule } from '@angular/core'; import { AdminUserLoginComponent } from './admin-user-login.component'; import { RouterModule } from '@angular/router'; import { AdminUserLoginRouteChildren } from './admin-user-login.route'; @NgModule({ declarations: [AdminUserLoginComponent], imports: [ RouterModule.forChild(AdminUserLoginRouteChildren), ], exports: [AdminUserLoginComponent] }) export class AdminUserLoginModule { } // projects/admin-user-login/src/public-api.ts /* * Public API Surface of admin-user-login */ export * from './lib/admin-user-login.service'; export * from './lib/admin-user-login.component'; export * from './lib/admin-user-login.module'; export * from './lib/admin-user-login.route'; ``` 3. run build ```s ng build admin-user-login ``` ## üî• Exception or Error 



ERROR: You must set "output.dir" instead of "output.file" when generating multiple chunks.
An unhandled exception occurred: You must set "output.dir" instead of "output.file" when generating multiple chunks.
See "/private/var/folders/gn/mbh35twj2yl1cbb9dszc7sm40000gn/T/ng-G9tuPy/angular-errors.log" for further details.

Issues.Title: feat(@angular-devkit/build-optimizer): don't use getImportTslibTransformer
Issues.Body:
This transformer can cause size regressions when it introduces `tslib` imports across independent chunks.

It should be deprecated because tslib adoption has become more ubiquitous.

Should also speed up Build Optimizer processing time because there's one less thing to do.

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): re-introduce pure_getters
Issues.Body:
PR #15607 removed the `_pure_getters` optimization as it no longer has effect on the framework size.
But it does have an effect on third party library.

For example a simple project using `@ng-bootstrap/ng-bootstrap` goes from `444K` uncompressed with CLI `9.0.0-next.5` to `488K` with CLI `9.0.0-next.6` which introduced the removal.

Issues.Title: normalize angular project layouts
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
```
- [x] update
- [x] lint
```

### Description
We have made changes to the "standard" Angular project config (tsconfig.json -> tsconfig.app.json for example) throughout the evolution of the CLI. Due to the power of `angular.json`, old projects keep working, but don't look like newer projects.


### Describe the solution you'd like
Although old projects keep working, it would be better to standardize what we create as `ng new` as official/canonical/expected/normal by adding update schematics to move the various files to match our latest expectations.

This will also make writing future schematics easier because we can make more assumptions about the Angular workspace layout.


See a discussion about some of this on Material here: https://github.com/angular/material.angular.io/pull/641/files/ab9ba476fc9f4eb3007afdb18e0732eb0c8c053c#r330673934
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "normalize angular project layouts" (#15741)

Issues.Title: New default route config proposal
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
```
- [x] new
- [x] generate
- [x] add
```

### Description
Right now when you create an application with routing, it creates an AppRoutingModule. This is an extra NgModule that doesn't do anything (it doesn't change the injector config, and it isn't used for compilation of any templates).


### Describe the solution you'd like
Remove it and just export the route config directly.

https://github.com/StephenFluin/new-routeconfig-proposal/commit/558c655bdc3c440d10b98fc0749c28d4f3665e24

### Describe alternatives you've considered
We could also do this 100% in the AppModule, or export const ROUTECONFIG = RouterModule.forRoot(...) to get the same providers without the extra wrapper.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "New default route config proposal" (#15740)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-optimizer): fix error when `__decorate` has‚Ä¶
Issues.Body:
‚Ä¶ no `__metadata`

When a __decorator expression has no __metadata call, example:

```
__decorate([
    ContentChild('heading', { read: ElementRef, static: true })
], FooBarComponent.prototype, "buttons", void 0);
```

A Cannot read property 'kind' of undefined error will be thrown.

Closes: #15703
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(@angular-devkit/build-optimizer): fix error when `__decorate` has‚Ä¶" (#15737)

Issues.Title: passing a Tree & Rules between schematics
Issues.Body:
if I have two (or more) schematics that must be executed in sequence, 
I want to create the initial Tree and pass it to the first schematic which returns a Rule,
and I want to pass the modified Tree (after applying the returned Rule from schematic #1) to the next schematic in sequence, ..and so on

so I need to get the last updated Tree after applying all Rules (in sequence) via all schematics and then execute schematics on the final Tree via node.js (not schematics cli)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "passing a Tree & Rules between schematics" (#15739)

Issues.Title: Dialog should not restore focus when it doesn't have the focus anymore
Issues.Body:
#### Bug, feature request, or proposal:
Bug

#### What are the steps to reproduce?
1. Open a material dialog
2. Call .close() on its ref
3. Synchronously move the focus to some element in your UI (not in the dialog).

Expected: 
The focus should remain where you put it.

Actual:
Asynchronously (when the close animation finishes), the dialog will restore focus to whatever element happened to have focus before the dialog was opened.

#### What is the use-case or motivation for changing an existing behavior?
This behavior is unexpected.

#### Is there anything else we should know?
Closure UI does it the way I suggest (it's where I got the idea): https://github.com/google/closure-library/blob/master/closure/goog/ui/modalpopup.js#L541
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Dialog should not restore focus when it doesn't have the focus anymore" (#17296)

Issues.Title: refactor: annotate remaining base classes with @directive for ivy
Issues.Body:
Some base classes define class members with Angular features. Therefore
they need to be decorated with `@directive()` so that the classes can be
extended in Ivy.

This is an official migration that will be performed for CLI
applications in version 9. angular/angular#32590.

Most of these classes do not cause issues yet because the removal of `ngBaseDef`
has not happened yet, but it is planned.. hence the actual migration in `@angular/core`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "refactor: annotate remaining base classes with @directive for ivy" (#17279)

Issues.Title: build: disable sourcemap generation for all sass binaries
Issues.Body:
We need to disable sourcemap generation for all sass binaries
as otherwise the inline source map comment will be inlined into
component `styles` in the release output.

Technically this is not a big deal for AOT compilation where those
source-map strings are omitted anyway, but for JIT it will contribute in
payload size, and with the current state of Angular Package Format, these
source-maps would point to non-existent files anyway.

We should just _not_ generate these sourcemaps/comments **similarly
to our Gulp build process**. Fortunately moving stuff to `defaults.bzl` macro's
makes future re-enabling a one-liner. Plus it's easier to remind where to import
rules from (potentially also helpful if the sass rules become a Bazel NPM workspace)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: disable sourcemap generation for all sass binaries" (#17291)

Issues.Title: build: generate api docs for all tertiary entry-points
Issues.Body:
Updates our Dgeni setup to generate API docs for all entry-points
which are configured in the `cdk/config.bzl` or `material/config.bzl` file. 

This basically means that we now generate API docs for `material/*/testing`
entry-points and for `cdk/testing/*`.

Removes the code that made `cdk/testing` a separate sub package. This
involves more code than just treating it as "real" entry-point (for which we generate bundles etc.).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: generate api docs for all tertiary entry-points" (#17293)

Issues.Title: build: publish snapshot scripts incorrectly updating unrelated code
Issues.Body:
I've been wondering for quite some time why a comment in the
cdk drag-drop changes sometimes in the `cdk-builds`.

Apparently it happens because the publish snapshot script used
the current version in the `package.json` as search pattern for
a sed call. This is breaky since the version includes a dot to
separate version segments. These dots are not interpreted as
dots, but rather as a RegExp special character.

Causing unrelated changes to comments that match e.g. `/8.2.0/`

https://github.com/angular/cdk-builds/commit/b3a86279410f3df409e1d1e4638b3b3ed20b8eef#diff-24a5156f00a6496d7fd08504682e8246R1952.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: publish snapshot scripts incorrectly updating unrelated code" (#17290)

Issues.Title: Disable a mat-step within Horizontal and Vertical Stepper
Issues.Body:
Description: I am submitting a feature request to add a simple [disable] property to a mat-step. This would allow you to pass in a boolean that's maintained in your component to disable or enable a mat-step dynamically. 

Use Case: I've come across a situation where I need to navigate to the third step of a horizontal stepper on 'view'. So basically skip all the creation and editing steps and just go straight to the step that shows my summary of what I've done. I searched for a while to try to find a nice way to disable a mat-step. People were suggesting using the [completed] or [editable] properties but none of those disabled the step. I was able to still navigate to it if and edit fields if I clicked on it. What I ended up doing was dynamically hiding the headers using css and [ngClass]. Obviously this is a bit of a hacky workaround and I'd love to just be able to disable the step by passing it a 'viewMode' boolean which I'm doing for other areas of the component to show and hide content I want the user to see based on what mode they're in. The UX designers at my company want to be able to see the other steps even though we wouldn't be able to navigate to them to keep the same look and feel. So essentially just make the header of the mat-step not clickable. I've hidden all the headers now as a temporary solution when user is in viewMode. Another problem with my workaround is I'm having to add a bunch of other styles that will be applied in viewMode because the headers take up a good 1/8th of my MatDialog so when they're not there, I found that I had to use [ngClass] in multiple areas. 

I hadn't found a better workaround then [ngClass] for this problem I'm having. If anyone has a better solution, I'd love to hear it.

Thanks

Don Miko
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Disable a mat-step within Horizontal and Vertical Stepper" (#17294)

Issues.Title: Autocomplete stops showing the List when clicking in the input field after adding a Mat-Chip
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: 
Official Demo shows this issue.
https://run.stackblitz.com/api/angular/v1?file=app%2Fchips-autocomplete-example.ts

This example starts showing a <mat-chip>Lemon in the autocomplete component.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Click in the Input of Autocomplete, next to the Lemon matchip
2. It properly shows the List associated
3. Click in an Option of the List, i.e "Apple". The mat-chip is added next to "Lemon".
4. Click in the Input of Autocomplete. Now it does not show the "List", as you would expect and as it did in step 2, which breaks the UIX.
5. Click outside the component (it loses the Focus)
6. Click again the Input field: it receives the Focus and the List is again shown.
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?
Users expect that clicking in the Input field would show them the List of options again, as it did in the very beginning without needing to use the "hackish" click out-and-in.


#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?
If a Mat-chip is added, the user needs to focus out and then click to set the Focus in, in order to have the List shown.

#### Environment

- Angular: 8.1.0
- CDK/Material: Material 8.0.2
- Browser(s): Chrome, Safari, Firefox
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows, Ubuntu, MacOS
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Autocomplete stops showing the List when clicking in the input field after adding a Mat-Chip" (#17292)

Issues.Title: cdkDrag breaks scrolling when element dropped to original position
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Using a touch-screen laptop, go to https://stackblitz.com/edit/cdkdragstartdelay-bug-demo
2. Shorten the window so the scrollbar appears
3. Touch and hold an element for > 1 sec (because cdkDragStartDelay is set to 1000) and then drag around the screen - drop element back in original position
4. Attempt to scroll the page by touching the **same element** and moving up or down within 1 second (before cdkDragStartDelay elapses). Notice the page will not scroll unless you begin by touching anything other than that element.
 
#### Expected Behavior

The screen should scroll when swiping on the element I dragged within the cdkDragStartDelay limit.

#### Actual Behavior

Could not scroll.

#### Environment

- Angular: 8.2.9
- CDK/Material: 8.2.1
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):  Windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "cdkDrag breaks scrolling when element dropped to original position" (#17287)

Issues.Title: refactor(ng-update): do not visit external stylesheets multiple times
Issues.Body:
Besides stylesheets which are referenced in components, we also visit
stylesheets which are not referenced by a component. This has been done
at some point to capture global stylesheets.

Right now we accidentally visit external stylesheets multiple times. This can
result in broken stylesheets.

Also this commit does some path manipulation cleanup.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "refactor(ng-update): do not visit external stylesheets multiple times" (#17286)

Issues.Title: build: re-add theming scss bundle to material package
Issues.Body:
Re-adds the `_theming.scss` bundle the to the Material
release package. We previously switched it to a simple
sass file that did not bundle all imported mixins.

We need to switch it back to a bundle since we observed
that importing individual files is slower than accessing
the bundled sass file.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: re-add theming scss bundle to material package" (#17278)

Issues.Title: Double role definition in calendar-body.html
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

There are two role definitions, one `role="gridcell"` and another `role="button"`, isn't it supposed to be only one?

The 2nd role was added about 3 months ago.

https://github.com/angular/components/blob/master/src/material/datepicker/calendar-body.html#L31

https://github.com/angular/components/blob/master/src/material/datepicker/calendar-body.html#L43
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

To have single role on each `<td>`


#### Actual Behavior

There are two `role` definitions for each `<td>`


#### Environment

- Material -> Datepicker -> Calender body
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Double role definition in calendar-body.html" (#17280)

Issues.Title: IE11: Incorrect width of mat-select
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Set the width of the mat-select to something like 40px.

#11609
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

Width of the drop down to be the same in IE as it is in Chrome


#### Actual Behavior

Width of the drop down is not the same in IE as it is in Chrome but is instead 40px wide


#### Environment

- Angular: 8.1.0
- CDK/Material: 8.1.0
- Browser(s): Chromium: 76.0.3809.100, IE: 11.737.17763.0 
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS

#### Notes

The solution mentioned in #11609 solves the issue

`  
.cdk-overlay-pane {
    display: block;
}
`
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "IE11: Incorrect width of mat-select" (#17276)

Issues.Title: build: fix write permissions for bazel npm_package output
Issues.Body:
We need to update permissions for the copied "npm_package". Bazel makes these files readonly
in the "bazel-out", but for publishing, they should be writable. Also it's necessary in order to be able to update the "package.json" version
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: fix write permissions for bazel npm_package output" (#17273)

Issues.Title: build: do generate invalid semver versions for snapshot builds
Issues.Body:
Apparently there is a long-standing issue in the snapshot builds
where we generate invalid versions if the snapshot SHA starts with
zero's. In order to fix this, we need to ensure that the commit SHA is
part of a version segment that starts with text (i.e. `-sha-{val}`).

This happens rarely, but it should be a good idea to fix this.

**Note**: I guess this should also go into the patch branch for the `8.2.x` docs-content.

Fixes #17264
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: do generate invalid semver versions for snapshot builds" (#17267)

```

ERROR TypeError: Cannot read property 'slice' of null

ERROR TypeError: Cannot read property 'length' of null

    at MapSubscriber.project (table.es5.js:655)

    at MapSubscriber.push../node_modules/rxjs/_esm5/internal/Subscriber.js.Subscriber.next (Subscriber.js:53)
    at CombineLatestSubscriber.push../node_modules/rxjs/_esm5/internal/observable/combineLatest.js.CombineLatestSubscriber.notifyNext (combineLatest.js:83)
    at InnerSubscriber.push../node_modules/rxjs/_esm5/internal/InnerSubscriber.js.InnerSubscriber._next (InnerSubscriber.js:15)

```

    "@angular/animations": "~7.2.13",
    "@angular/cdk": "~7.3.7",

Issues.Title: Datepicker add possibility to change today highlight
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

Today is currently highlighted considering the browser timezone, it is not possible to configure a custom timezone or configure a different date for "today".

#### Use Case

This feature would be useful in applications that use a custom timezone configuration in application settings instead of browser's timezone.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Datepicker add possibility to change today highlight" (#17269)
